While the official course description and learning outcomes in the source document contain clerical errors (referencing programming and calculus), the detailed teaching plan outlines a curriculum focused on IT fundamentals rather than pure programming or mathematics.

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **IT Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the history and evolution of computing, the computing profession, and Number Systems .
* **System Architecture (Weeks 4-5):** Examines key components of computer systems, Operating Systems, Hardware/Software definitions, and introduces concepts of Malware and Viruses .
* **Connectivity & Security (Weeks 6-7):** Focuses on Computer Security (Hacking, Phishing, Privacy Acts) and Internet fundamentals (Protocols, WWW, Cyberspace) .
* **Web Technologies (Weeks 8-9):** Introduces HTML and CSS for website structure and design .
* **Systems Concepts (Weeks 10-12):** Covers Computer Organization and Architecture, Global Information Systems, and the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) .
* **Enterprise Applications (Weeks 13-14):** Explores Enterprise Systems (Supply Chain Management, CRM, ERP) and Management Support Systems (Decision Support, Executive Information Systems) .
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-17):** Introduces Intelligent Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Neural Networks) and emerging trends such as Virtual Reality, RFID, and Nanotechnology .

**Assessment & Resources:**
Grading is weighted towards Performance Tasks (50%), followed by Written Work (25%) and Term Assessments (25%). The primary text reference is "Hands on Virtual Computing" by Simpson.

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Laboratory)
content:
DSALGLAB - Data Structure and Algorithm (Laboratory) is a course with a credit value of 2 units (lecture) and 2 contact hours per week, according to the document. It serves as a prerequisite to MICROBOT and requires IPROGLAB as a prerequisite. The course covers abstract data types (ADTs) and the implementation of fundamental data structures, including arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees. It also covers internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management .

**Weekly Content Plan:**
* **Fundamentals (Week 2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Algorithms, and Abstract Data Types .
* **Arrays (Weeks 3-4):** Covers Linear Arrays, Multi-Dimensional Arrays, Dynamic Arrays, and operations on arrays .
* **Linked Lists (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of Singly Linked Lists, Doubly Linked Lists, and Circular Linked Lists .
* **Recursion (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on recursive definitions, writing recursive programs, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks and Queues (Weeks 10-12):** Covers Stack representation and operations , followed by Queue representation and operations .
* **Trees (Weeks 13-14):** topics include Binary Trees, Tree Representation, Expression Trees, and Tree Traversal applications .
* **Sorting (Weeks 15-16):** Covers various sorting algorithms including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Introduces Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Tools and Resources:**
The reference materials suggest the use of **C++** as the primary programming language for implementation. Assessment is based on Performance Tasks (50%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (25%).

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
content:
DSALGLEC - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture) is a 2-unit lecture course designed to introduce students to abstract data types and the implementation of fundamental data structures. The course requires IPROGLEC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT. The curriculum covers the design and implementation of data structures such as arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees, alongside internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management. 

**Weekly Course Outline:**
* **Foundations (Week 2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Algorithms, and Abstract Data Types (ADTs) .
* **Linear Structures (Weeks 3-6):** Detailed study of Arrays (linear, multi-dimensional, dynamic) and Operations on Arrays, followed by Linked Lists (singly, doubly, and circular) .
* **Recursion (Weeks 7-8):** Covers recursive definitions, processes, writing recursive programs, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stack and Queue ADTs (Weeks 10-12):** Focuses on the representation and operations of Stacks and Queues .
* **Hierarchical Structures (Weeks 13-14):** Introduction to Trees, specifically Binary Trees, their representation, traversals, and applications such as Expression Trees .
* **Sorting Algorithms (Weeks 15-16):** Examination of various sorting methods including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Covers Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Assessment and Resources:**
Grading is calculated based on Written Work (25%), Performance Tasks (45%), and Term Assessments (30%). Recommended learning resources indicate the use of C++ as the primary programming language for demonstrating these concepts.

DISCMATH - Discrete Mathematics is a 3-unit lecture course covering the fundamental mathematical structures and logic essential for computer science. It has no prerequisites. 

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
Although some sections of the source document contain clerical errors referencing programming descriptions or calculus outcomes, the detailed **Teaching and Learning Plan** confirms the specific curriculum as follows:
* **Sets and Logic (Weeks 2-4, 7-8):** Covers Set Theory (definitions, operations), Induction (strong induction), and Mathematical Logic (propositions, predicates, quantifiers, negations, logical connectives, tautologies, and inference).
* **Proof Techniques & Number Theory (Weeks 4-6):** Includes direct proofs, proofs by contradiction, Divisibility (division algorithm, GCD), Prime Numbers (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic), and Modular Arithmetic (congruence).
* **Relations and Functions (Week 7):** Differentiates between relations and functions, covering ordered pairs and types of relations.
* **Counting Principles (Weeks 9-12):** Post-midterm topics include Fundamental Counting Principles, Binomial Coefficients, the Binomial Theorem, the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle, Derangements, and the Pigeonhole Principle.
* **Algorithms and Complexity (Weeks 13-14):** Introduces Asymptotic Notation (Big O) and properties for analyzing algorithm time complexity.
* **Graph Theory and Trees (Weeks 14-17):** Extensive coverage of Graphs (common types, Eulerian, Bipartite, Colored, Planar graphs, Euler's formula) and Trees (basic properties, spanning trees).

**Assessment:**
Grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (30%).

DISCSTRU - Discrete Structure 1 is a 3-unit lecture course that provides a foundation in the mathematical structures used in computer science. It has no prerequisites. Although the provided syllabus document contains clerical errors in the 'Course Description' and 'Learning Outcomes' sections (incorrectly listing programming and calculus topics), the detailed **Teaching and Learning Plan** outlines a rigorous curriculum in Discrete Mathematics .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Sets and Induction (Weeks 2-4):** Covers Set Theory (notation, operations), and Mathematical Induction (including strong induction) .
* **Number Theory & Proofs (Weeks 5-6):** Topics include Direct Proofs, Proof by Contradiction, Divisibility, the Division Algorithm, Greatest Common Divisors (GCD), Prime Numbers, the Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic, and Modular Arithmetic .
* **Logic, Relations, & Functions (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Relations (ordered pairs, kinds of relations), Functions, and Mathematical Logic (propositions, predicates, quantifiers, logical connectives, and tautologies) .
* **Combinatorics (Weeks 10-12):** Post-midterm content focuses on Counting Principles, Binomial Coefficients, the Binomial Theorem, and the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle .
* **Asymptotic Analysis (Weeks 13-14):** Introduces Asymptotic Notation for analyzing algorithm time complexity .
* **Graph Theory (Weeks 13-17):** Extensive coverage of Graphs (common types, Eulerian, Bipartite, Colored), Trees (spanning trees), and Planar Graphs (Euler's formula, coloring) .

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Written Work (25%), and Term Assessments (30%).

IPROGLAB - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Laboratory) is a 1-unit laboratory course with 3 contact hours per week. It requires FPROGLAB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for DSALGLAB. The course utilizes C++ to train students in designing, implementing, testing, and debugging programs using intermediate programming constructs .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals & Operators (Weeks 2-4):** Covers C++ elements (reserved words, constants, basic types) and various operators (arithmetic, logical, relational, bitwise, assignment, increment/decrement) .
* **Control Structures (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of control flow including compound statements, conditional statements (If, If-else, Switch), and iteration constructs (For, While, Do-while loops) .
* **Modular Programming (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on C++ Functions, including structure, prototyping, return data types, parameters, and function overloading .
* **Memory Management & Strings (Weeks 10-12):** Detailed study of Pointers (declaring, reference/dereference operators, null pointers, pointers to pointers/functions) and String manipulation (declaration, initialization, functions) .
* **Data Structures & Files (Weeks 13-16):** Covers Structures (nesting, pointers to structures) and File handling (File class, streams, reading/writing records, random access files) .
* **Object-Oriented Concepts (Weeks 17-18):** Introduces principles of Object-Oriented Programming including Classes (private/public sections), Encapsulation, Real Objects, Constructors, and Destructors .

**Assessment:**
Grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes (limits, derivatives) in the Outcomes section; this summary relies on the Course Description and Weekly Content Plan which correctly describe an Intermediate C++ Programming course.)*

source: OBTL Plan - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming - Lec)
content:
IPROGLEC - Computer Programming 2 (Intermediate Programming) (Lecture) is a course designed to train students in designing, implementing, testing, and debugging programs using intermediate constructs of a general-purpose programming language, specifically C++. The syllabus lists the course credit as 1 unit with 3 contact hours per week, identifies **FPROGLAB** as a prerequisite, and notes that it serves as a prerequisite for **DSALGLAB** .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals (Weeks 1-2):** Orientation and a review of C++ elements including reserved words, constants, and basic data types .
* **Operators and Expressions (Weeks 3-4):** Detailed study of arithmetic, logical, relational, bitwise, assignment, and increment/decrement operators .
* **Control Structures (Weeks 5-6):** Implementation of control flow statements including compound statements, conditional statements (If, If-else, Switch), and iteration (For, While, Do-while loops) .
* **Modular Programming (Weeks 7-8):** Focuses on C++ Functions, covering structure, prototyping, return data types, parameters, and function overloading .
* **Memory Management (Weeks 10-11):** Comprehensive coverage of Pointers, including declaration, reference/dereference operators, null pointers, and pointers to pointers or functions .
* **String Manipulation (Weeks 11-12):** String declaration, initialization, and string functions .
* **Complex Data Types (Weeks 13-14):** Introduction to Structures, nesting structures, and pointers to structures .
* **File Handling (Weeks 15-16):** Using File classes and streams, reading/writing to files, and handling random access files .
* **Object-Oriented Programming (Weeks 17-18):** Introduction to Objects, Class encapsulation (Private/Public sections), Constructors, Destructors, and Class Header files .

**Assessment:**
The grading system is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

*(Note: The provided source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes in the Outcomes section; this summary relies on the Course Description and Weekly Plan which correctly describe a C++ Programming curriculum.)*

BUSANALY - Business Analytics is a 2-unit lecture course designed to introduce students to the field of business intelligence and data analysis. 

**Curriculum Note:**
While the "Course Description" section of the source document erroneously describes operating systems and computer architecture (Platform Technologies) , the **Teaching and Learning Plan** outlines a curriculum strictly focused on Business Analytics, Data Mining, and Business Intelligence .

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-4):** Covers the history of Business Analytics, Business Intelligence (BI) concepts, Pattern Recognition, Data Processing, Decision Types, and BI Tools/Skills .
* **Data Management (Week 5):** detailed study of Data Warehousing, including design considerations, development approaches, architecture, and ETL (Data Loading) processes .
* **Data Mining Fundamentals (Week 6):** Introduction to Data Mining, data cleaning/preparation, and evaluation of outputs .
* **Predictive Modeling (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Decision Trees (construction and algorithms) and Regression Analysis (Linear vs. Logistic, correlations vs. relationships) .
* **Advanced Analytics (Weeks 10-11):** Introduction to Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) design principles and Cluster Analysis (specifically K-Means Algorithm) .
* **Pattern Discovery (Week 12):** Association Rule Mining and the application of the Apriori Algorithm .
* **Unstructured Data (Week 14):** Text Mining (mining the TDM) and Web Mining (Content, Structure, and Usage mining) .
* **Emerging Technologies (Weeks 14-17):** Exploration of Big Data (landscape, technologies, management) and a Data Modelling Primer (Relational Data Models, Data Management Systems) .

**Assessment:**
Grades are calculated based on Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

DSALGLAB - Data Structure Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course characterized by 3 contact hours per week. It requires IPROGLAB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT. The course emphasizes training students to design, implement, test, and debug programs using fundamental data structures and abstract data types .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Arrays (Weeks 1-2):** Implementation of Linear, Multi-dimensional, and Dynamic Arrays, including initialization, declaration, and searching (exact and range matching) .
* **Linked Lists (Weeks 3-4):** Creation and manipulation of Singly, Doubly, and Circular Linked Lists using dynamic storage .
* **Recursion (Weeks 5-6):** Covers recursive definitions, identifying base/general cases, simulating recursion, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks (Weeks 7-8):** Stack representation, operations, and implementation as arrays .
* **Queues (Weeks 10-11):** Declaration, initialization, and operations of Queues .
* **Trees (Weeks 12-13):** Focuses on Binary Trees, tree representation, representing lists as binary trees, and tree traversals (including expression trees) .
* **Sorting (Weeks 14-16):** Implementation of various sorting algorithms including Exchange, Selection, Tree, Insertion, Merge, and Radix Sorts .
* **Graphs (Week 17):** Covers Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Tools and Assessment:**
The course utilizes **C++** as the primary programming language for all laboratory exercises. Assessment is heavily weighted towards Performance Tasks (45%) and Term Assessments (30%), with Written Work accounting for 25%. 

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes in the text ; this summary follows the correct Data Structures curriculum outlined in the teaching plan.)*

INFOMGMTLB - Information Management Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course characterized by 3 contact hours per week. It requires INTCOMLB as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for OOPRGLAB. While the source document's official description and learning outcomes contain clerical errors (referencing general programming and calculus) , the detailed Teaching and Learning Plan describes a comprehensive survey of Information Systems concepts and applications.

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the overview of Information Systems (IS), Computer and Information Literacy, Transaction Processing, MIS, and the history/components of computer hardware and software .
* **Data Management (Week 4):** Introduction to Database Systems, Data Warehouses, and Data Marts, including DBMS components and trends .
* **Ethics & Security (Weeks 5-6):** Examines Personal, Legal, Ethical, and Organizational issues, privacy concerns, computer crime, and methods for Protecting Information Resources .
* **Connectivity (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Data Communication systems, Network configurations, Wireless concepts, and the infrastructure of the Internet, Intranets, and Extranets (including Web 2.0/3.0) .
* **Business Applications (Week 10-11):** Explores E-commerce (B2C, B2B models) and Global Information Systems .
* **System Development (Week 12):** Detailed study of Building Successful Information Systems using the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) phases: Planning, Requirements, Design, Implementation, and Maintenance .
* **Enterprise Systems (Week 13):** Covers Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Knowledge Management, and Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) .
* **Decision Support (Week 14):** Introduction to Management Support Systems, Decision Support Systems (DSS), and Executive Information Systems (EIS) .
* **Intelligent Systems (Week 15):** Overview of Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Fuzzy Logic, Neural Networks, and Natural Language Processing .
* **Emerging Trends (Weeks 16-17):** Discussion of SaaS, Virtual Reality, RFID, Biometrics, and Nanotechnology .

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

INFMGTLC - Information Management Lecture is a 2-unit lecture course with a duration of 2 contact hours per week. It requires INTCOMLC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for OOPRGLEC. While the official course description and learning outcomes in the source document contain clerical errors (referencing general programming and calculus), the detailed Teaching and Learning Plan outlines a curriculum focused on the theoretical foundations of Information Systems (IS).

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Foundations (Weeks 1-3):** Covers the overview of Information Systems, Computer Literacy, Transaction Processing Systems, and the fundamental components of computers (Hardware, Software, Input/Output).
* **Data Management (Week 4):** Explores Database Systems, Database Management Systems (DBMS), Data Warehouses, and Data Marts.
* **Ethics & Security (Weeks 5-6):** Examines Personal, Legal, Ethical, and Organizational issues in IS, alongside Computer and Network Security threats and safeguards.
* **Connectivity (Weeks 7-8):** Covers Data Communication systems, Network configurations, Wireless concepts, and Internet technologies (Intranets, Extranets, Web 2.0/3.0).
* **Business Applications (Week 10-11):** Detailed study of E-commerce models (B2C, B2B) and Global Information Systems.
* **System Development (Week 12):** Focuses on the System Development Life Cycle (SDLC) phases: Planning, Requirements Gathering, Design, Implementation, and Maintenance.
* **Enterprise Systems (Weeks 13-14):** Covers Supply Chain Management (SCM), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), and Management Support Systems (DSS, EIS).
* **Advanced Topics (Weeks 15-17):** Introduces Intelligent Information Systems (Artificial Intelligence, Expert Systems, Neural Networks) and Emerging Trends such as SaaS, Virtual Reality, RFID, and Biometrics.

**Assessment:**
The course grading is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

PTECHLEC - Platform Technologies Lecture is a 2-unit lecture course with 2 contact hours per week . It requires IPATLEC1 as a prerequisite . The course covers the major components of Platform Technologies, specifically Operating Systems and Computer Architecture/Organization. 

**Course Content & Weekly Plan:**
* **Operating Systems (Weeks 2-4):** Covers the history and types of Operating Systems, the Processor, and RAM .
* **Binary Operations (Weeks 5-8):** Focuses on binary addition and multiplication, Logic Gates & Symbols, and Boolean Algebra .
* **Scheduling Algorithms (Weeks 10-12):** Examines Non-Preemptive (FCFS, SJF, Priority) and Pre-emptive (Shortest Remaining Time First, Round Robin, Multi-Level Queue) algorithms .
* **Assembly Language (Week 13):** Introduces basic assembly language variables, operations, and control flows .
* **Computer Organization (Weeks 14-15):** Discusses Enterprise Software, Middleware, Frameworks, and Enterprise Management Software configuration .
* **Firmware and Hardware (Weeks 16-17):** Covers firmware storage options, versioning, digital logic, digital systems, benchmarking, and serial vs. parallel processing .

**Assessment:**
The grading system is weighted as follows: Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

PTECHLAB - Platform Technologies Laboratory is a 1-unit laboratory course with 3 contact hours per week . It requires IPATLAB1 as a prerequisite . The course complements the lecture component by covering the practical aspects of operating systems, computer architecture, and organization.

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **OS & Architecture Review (Weeks 2-4):** Practical review of Operating System types and Computer Architecture (Processor and RAM) .
* **Binary & Logic Operations (Weeks 5-8):** Performing binary addition and multiplication, and converting binary terms using logic gates and Boolean Algebra .
* **Scheduling Algorithms (Weeks 10-12):** Tracing and simulation of Non-Preemptive (FCFS, SJF, Priority) and Pre-emptive (SRTF, Round Robin, Multi-Level Queue) scheduling algorithms .
* **Assembly Language (Week 13):** Demonstration and understanding of basic assembly language commands, variables, operations, and control flows .
* **System Organization (Weeks 14-15):** Comparing Operating System types and Computer system units, including Enterprise Software and Middleware configuration .
* **Hardware & Firmware (Weeks 16-17):** Reviewing current hardware/software prices, firmware storage options, digital logic systems, and benchmarking costs/benefits .

**Assessment:**
Grading is determined by Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%).

source: OBTL Plan - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture)
content:
DSALGLEC - Data Structure and Algorithm (Lecture) is a 2-unit lecture course involving 2 contact hours per week . It requires IPROGLEC as a prerequisite and serves as a prerequisite for MICROBOT . The course explores abstract data types (ADTs) and the implementation of fundamental data structures, including arrays, stacks, queues, linked lists, and mapping trees. It also covers internal and external searching and sorting algorithms and dynamic storage management .

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Fundamentals (Weeks 1-2):** Introduction to Data Structures, Abstract Data Types, and the difference between static and dynamic implementations .
* **Linear Data Structures (Weeks 3-5):** In-depth study of Arrays (Linear, Multi-Dimensional, Dynamic) and Linked Lists (Singly, Doubly, Circular) .
* **Recursion (Week 6):** Recursive definitions, writing recursive programs, and analyzing efficiency .
* **Stacks and Queues (Weeks 7-11):** Representation, operations, and applications of Stacks and Queues .
* **Trees (Weeks 12-13):** Binary Trees, Tree Representation, Tree Traversals, and Expression Trees .
* **Sorting Algorithms (Weeks 14-15):** Analysis of various sorting techniques including Exchange, Selection, Insertion, Merge, and Radix Sorts .
* **Graphs (Weeks 16-17):** Directed and Undirected Graphs, Graph Representations, Search Algorithms, Shortest Path Problems, and Spanning Trees .

**Assessment:**
Course assessment relies on Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%). The primary programming language referenced for implementation concepts is C++. 

*(Note: The source document contains a clerical error listing Calculus learning outcomes in the text ; this summary follows the correct Data Structures curriculum outlined in the teaching plan.)*

source: OBTL Plan - Integrative Programming and Technologies (Laboratory)
content:
IPATLAB1 - Integrative Programming and Technologies (Laboratory) is a 1-unit laboratory course with 3 contact hours per week . It requires WEBDVLB2 and INTROHCI as prerequisites and serves as a prerequisite for PFORMTEC . The course focuses on integrating various programming technologies and methodologies to develop comprehensive software solutions.

**Weekly Course Content:**
* **Foundations (Week 2):** Introduction to Integrative Programming, Programming Languages, Database, and Network concepts.
* **Language Paradigms (Weeks 3-6):** Comparative analysis of Compiled vs. Interpretive Languages, and Application vs. Scripting Languages.
* **Object-Oriented Integration (Weeks 7-8):** Application of Inheritance and Polymorphism in an integrative coding context, including Interface implementation.
* **Data Integration (Weeks 10-13):** Introduction to Programming with HTML, XSL, XSLT, and XPath for data mapping and display.
* **Scripting Technologies (Weeks 14-15):** Creating and executing scripts using PHP, JavaScript, Python, and JQuery, and understanding their role in programming.
* **Integrative Development (Weeks 16-17):** Advanced integrative coding, design, and implementation of Web Applications involving Database and Network components.

**Assessment:**
Grading is determined by Performance Tasks (45%), Term Assessments (30%), and Written Work (25%) .

DBMSLAB2 - Database Management System 2 is a 1-unit laboratory course (3 hours/week) with a prerequisite of **DBMSLAB1**. This course engages students in the analysis of complex business scenarios to create a **data model** (a conceptual representation of an organization's information). Students implement their database design by creating a **physical database using SQL**. The course culminates in a project that requires students to design, implement, and demonstrate a database solution for a business or organization. A review of basic SQL syntax and rules is included, before advancing to more advanced skills in designing and programming databases, including the **SQL Programming language to an advanced level**. The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) focus on learning the techniques and tools to design, build, and extract information from a database, and possessing basic mathematical, logical, and analytical problem-solving skills. The weekly content is structured as follows:

* **Weeks 2-3:** Creating other **Schema Objects** (Views, Sequences, Indexes, Synonyms) and an **Introduction to PL/SQL** (Benefits, Types of PL/SQL Blocks, Programming Environment) .
* **Week 4:** **Declaring PL/SQL Variables** (Declaring, Initializing, Data Types, Bind Variables, assigning new values) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **Writing Executable Statements** (Lexical units, Built-in SQL Functions, Implicit and Explicit Conversion, Nested Blocks) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Interacting with the Database Server** (SQL statements in PL/SQL, SQL Cursor Attributes, Database Architecture, Application Development) .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Writing Control Structures** (Overview of Control Structure, IF and CASE Statements, LOOP and EXIT Statements for controlling loop iterations) .
* **Week 12:** **Working with Composite Data Types** (PL/SQL Records, PL/SQL Collections, Bulk-binding collections) .
* **Week 13:** **Using Explicit Cursors** (Implicit and Explicit Cursors, managing cursors, processing transactions, safeguarding the database) .
* **Week 14:** **Handling Exceptions** (Predefined, Non-predefined, and User-defined Exceptions) .
* **Week 15:** **Creating Procedures and Functions** (Creating, Calling, and Passing Parameters) .
* **Week 16:** **Creating Packages and Working With Packages** (Components, Creating/Invoking, Overloading Procedures/Functions, Initialization Block) .
* **Week 17:** **Creating Triggers** (Generating derived column values, Creating Database Triggers, Firing Rules, Enforcing referential integrity, Imposing security authorizations) .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination .

The course utilizes **PowerPoint Presentations, Modules, Video Presentations, Internet Connection, and Google Classroom** as Learning and Teaching Support Materials (LTSM).

DBMSLEC2 - **Database Management System 2** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hours/week) with a prerequisite of **DBMSLEC1**. This course trains students to analyze complex business scenarios and create a **data model**a conceptual representation of an organization's information. Students will learn to implement database designs by creating a **physical database using SQL**. The course culminates in a project that challenges students to design, implement, and demonstrate a database solution for a business or organization. A review of basic **SQL syntax** is included, before students advance to more sophisticated skills in designing and programming databases, learning the **SQL Programming language to an advanced level**. The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILO) focus on designing, building, and extracting information from a database and developing analytical problem-solving skills .

**Key topics covered include:**

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Creating other Schema Objects** (Views, Sequences, Indexes, Synonyms) and an **Introduction to PL/SQL** (Benefits, Types of PL/SQL Blocks, Programming Environment) .
* **Week 4:** **Declaring PL/SQL Variables** (Declaring, Initializing, Data Types, Bind Variables) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **Writing Executable Statements** (Lexical units, Built-in SQL Functions, Implicit and Explicit Conversion, Nested Blocks) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Interacting with the Database Server** (SQL statements in PL/SQL, SQL Cursor Attributes, Database Architecture, Application Development) .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Writing Control Structures** (Overview of PL/SQL Control Structure, IF and CASE Statements, LOOP and EXIT Statements) .
* **Week 12:** **Working with Composite Data Types** (PL/SQL Records, PL/SQL Collections, Bulk-binding collections) .
* **Week 13:** **Using Explicit Cursors** (Implicit and Explicit Cursors, managing cursors, processing transactions, and database safeguarding) .
* **Week 14:** **Handling Exceptions** (Predefined, Non-predefined, and User-defined Exceptions) .
* **Week 15:** **Creating Procedures and Functions** (Creating, Calling, and Passing Parameters) .
* **Week 16:** **Creating Packages and Working With Packages** (Components, Overloading Procedures/Functions, Initialization Block) .
* **Week 17:** **Creating Triggers** (Database Trigger Firing Rules, Enforcing referential integrity, Imposing security authorizations) .

The course uses **PowerPoint Presentations, Modules, Video Presentation, Internet Connection, Google Classroom, and Google Meet** for instruction.

WEBDEVLC2 - **Web Development 2 (Lecture)** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hrs/week) with a prerequisite of **WEBDVLC1** and is a prerequisite for **WEBDVLC3**. This course focuses on the development of software design and construction, emphasizing **Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) libraries and design patterns**. Topics include OOP design, design patterns, testing, **Graphical User Interface (GUI)**, OOP libraries, software engineering strategies, and approaches to programming in teams. The intended learning outcomes (CILOs) are highly unusual, primarily listing objectives related to **Calculus** and **Differential Equations** (e.g., evaluating limits, defining continuity, applying differentiation rules, computing antiderivatives, solving problems involving areas and volumes). 

**Note**: The CILOs for this specific syllabus appear to be a boilerplate error, listing mathematical topics instead of web development outcomes. However, the weekly teaching plan details core web development concepts:

* **Week 2:** **JavaScript Overview** (Introduction to Programming on the web, adding JavaScript to a page, tracking errors, creating smart web forms).
* **Weeks 3-4:** **JavaScript Grammar and Logic** (Statements, Data Types, Variables, Arrays, Conditional Statements like If, Else If, Nesting Condition, and Control Flow using **While** and **For Loops**).
* **Week 5:** **jQuery Overview** (JavaScript Libraries, Introduction to jQuery, understanding the **Document Object Model (DOM)**, adding/manipulating page elements and content).
* **Week 6:** **Action/Reaction for Events** (Defining events, using events in jQuery, advanced event management).
* **Week 7-8:** **Animations and Effects** (Overview of Animation/Effect, adding jQuery effects/slider effects, Animated Dashboard, improving images, using Photo Gallery with effects like **jQuery Fancy Box**).
* **Week 10:** **Improving Navigations** (Basic links, adding external links in new windows, creating new windows, animated navigation bar using **HTML, CSS, and JavaScript**).
* **Weeks 11-12:** **Web Form Enhancement** (Forms Overview, smart forms, basic forms enhancement, and **Form validation**).
* **Week 13:** **Expanding Web Interface** (Organizing information in **Tabbed Panels**, Content Slider, determining size/position of page elements, **Tooltips**).
* **Weeks 14-15:** **Introduction to Ajax** (Ajax overview and function, basic Ajax, adding Ajax within jQuery, **JSON** overview/object/functions, accessing Complex JSON Data, Advanced jQuery tips).
* **Week 16:** **Advance JavaScript** (Working with Strings, Numbers, Dates and Times, writing more efficient JavaScript, generating dates for calendar pages).
* **Week 17:** **Troubleshooting and Debugging** (Fixing common programming mistakes, debugging incorrect paths, variables, functions, and using tools like **Firebug**).

Key resources for the course include **HTML, CSS, JavaScript, jQuery, Ajax, and JSON**.

source: OBTL Plan - INTEGRATIVE PROGRAMMING AND TECHNOLOGIES (Lecture)
content:
IPATLEC1 - **Integrative Programming and Technologies** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hrs/week) with prerequisites of **WEBDVLC2** and **INTROHCILC**, and is a prerequisite for **PFORMTEC**. The course covers the use of a **general-purpose programming language to solve problems**. The emphasis is to train students to design, implement, test, and debug programs intended to solve computing problems using **fundamental programming constructs** .

**Note**: The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) for this syllabus appear to be a boilerplate error, listing advanced mathematical topics (Calculus and Differential Equations) instead of programming outcomes. However, the weekly content outlines core programming and integration concepts:

* **Week 2:** **Introduction to Integrative Programming And Technologies** including general concepts of Programming Language, Database, and Network .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Compile vs Interpretive Language** (Describing and comparing the two language types) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **Application VS Scripting Language** (Describing and comparing Application Language vs. Scripting Language) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Integrative Coding 1** focusing on Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts such as **Inheritance**, **Polymorphism**, and **Interface** .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Introduction To Programming** covering foundational web technologies like **HTML**, and data transformation technologies like **XSL, XSLT, and XPath** (including implementation of XSL XSLT Data to HTML) .
* **Weeks 12-13:** **Data Mapping** (Implementing XPATH to HTML) .
* **Weeks 14-15:** **Scripting Technique** exploring languages and frameworks such as **PHP, JavaScript, Python, and JQuery** (covering the role of scripting, creating/executing scripts, and the influence of scripting on programming) .
* **Weeks 16-17:** **Integrative Coding 2** applying scripting techniques to Design, Coding, Database, Network, and Web Application contexts .

The course utilizes **PowerPoint presentations, Laptop/Computer Set, Handheld Devices, Module, Internet Connectivity, Google Classroom, and Google Meet/Zoom** for synchronous and asynchronous delivery.

NETWKLC1 - **Networking 1 (Lecture)** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hrs/week) with a prerequisite of **2nd Year Standing** and is a prerequisite for **NETWKLC2**. This course teaches the **fundamentals of networking**, covering both the practical and conceptual skills required for understanding basic networking. The course focuses on the architecture, components, and operations of **routers and switches** in a small network, including how to configure them for basic functionality .

**Note**: The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) for this syllabus appear to be a boilerplate error, listing advanced mathematical topics (Calculus and Differential Equations) instead of networking outcomes. However, the weekly content outlines core networking concepts:

* **Week 2:** **Exploring the Network** (Globally Connected **LANS**, **WANS**, and Internet, network topologies, converged networks, and requirements of a reliable network) .
* **Week 3:** **Configure a Network Operating System** (Cisco **IOS** Boot Camp, navigating and configuring Cisco IOS using the **CLI**, saving configurations, and configuring a host device with an **IP address**) .
* **Week 4:** **Network Protocols and Communication** (Rules of Communication, role of protocols and standards organizations in facilitating **interoperability**, and data transfer in the network) .
* **Week 5:** **Network Access and Ethernet** (**Physical Layer** Protocols, Network Media, **Data Link Layer**, **MAC**, **Ethernet Protocols**, **LAN Switches**, and **ARP**) .
* **Week 6:** **Network Layer** (Network Layer Protocols, **Routing**, **Routers**, and configuring routers with basic settings to enable end-to-end connectivity) .
* **Week 7:** **IP addressing and Subnetting** (**IPv4** and **IPv6** Network Addresses, purpose of the subnet mask, **unicast/broadcast/multicast** IPv4 addresses, **VLSM**, and configuring global unicast IPv6 addresses) .
* **Weeks 8:** **Transport and Application Layer** (Characteristics of **TCP** and **UDP**, TCP session establishment, Application Layer Protocols like **DNS** and **DHCP**, and file sharing services like **FTP** and **SMB** protocol) .
* **Week 10:** **Routing Concepts** (Functions of a router, initial configuration, routing decisions, path determination, and router operation including **encapsulation/de-encapsulation**) .
* **Week 11:** **Static Routing** (Advantages/disadvantages, configuring IPv4/IPv6 static and default routes, **CIDR** and **VLSM** review, configuring floating static routes, and troubleshooting static route issues) .
* **Weeks 12-13:** **Dynamic Routing and RIPng** (Purpose and types of dynamic routing protocols, **Distance Vector** and **Link State** routing, configuring **RIPv2**, and IPv4/IPv6 routing table entries) .
* **Weeks 14-15:** **EIGRP and EIGRPv6** (Features, implementation, and troubleshooting of **EIGRP** for IPv4/IPv6) .
* **Weeks 16-17:** **Single-Area OSPF** (Characteristics, messages, operations, and configuration of **OSPF**) .

Key readings include Cisco certification texts: *Cisco CCNA* and *CCNA Routing and Switching*. The course uses **PowerPoint presentations, Laptop/Computer Sets, Handheld Devices, Module, Internet Connectivity, Google Classroom, and Google Meet/Zoom** for instruction.

WEBDEVLC2 - **Web Development 2 (Lecture)** is a **3-unit lecture** course (3 hrs/week)  with a prerequisite of **WEBDVLC1** and is a prerequisite for **WEBDVLC3**. The course focuses on the development of software design and construction in the context of large **OOP libraries**. Emphasis is placed on **OOP design, design patterns, testing, Graphical User Interface (GUI)**, OOP libraries, software engineering strategies, and approaches to **programming in teams** .

**Note**: The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) for this syllabus appear to be a boilerplate error, listing advanced mathematical topics (Calculus and Differential Equations) instead of web development outcomes. However, the weekly teaching plan details core web development concepts:

* **Week 2:** **JavaScript Overview** (Introduction to Programming on the web, adding JavaScript to a page, tracking down errors, creating smart web forms) .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **JavaScript Grammar and Logic** (Statements, Data Types, Variables, Arrays, Conditional Statements, and Control flow using **While** and **For Loops**) .
* **Week 5:** **jQuery Overview** (JavaScript Libraries, Introduction to **jQuery**, understanding the **Document Object Model (DOM)**, adding content and tag attributes to pages) .
* **Week 6:** **Action/Reaction for Events** (Defining events, using event in jQuery, jQuery events concepts, and Advanced events management).
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Animations and Effects** (Adding jQuery effects/slider effects, adding Animated Dashboard, improving images, using **Photo Gallery** with effects like **jQuery Fancy Box**).  .
* **Week 10:** **Improving Navigations** (Basic links, adding external links in new windows/pages, and adding **animated navigation bar** using **HTML, CSS, and JavaScript**) .
* **Weeks 11-12:** **Web Form Enhancement** (Forms Overview, creating smart forms, basic enhancement, and **Form validation**) .
* **Week 13:** **Expanding Web Interface** (Organizing Information in **Tabbed Panels**, Content Slider, determining size and position of page elements, and **Tooltips**) .
* **Weeks 14-15:** **Introduction to Ajax** (Ajax overview, functions, basics, adding Ajax within jQuery, **JSON** overview/object/functions, accessing Complex JSON Data, and Advanced jQuery tips) .
* **Week 16:** **Advance JavaScript** (Working with Strings, Numbers, Dates and Times, and writing **More Efficient JavaScript**) .
* **Week 17:** **Troubleshooting and Debugging** (Fixing programming mistakes, debugging scripts, and using tools like **Firebug**) .

The required basic readings include texts on **Object-Oriented Analysis and Design**, **C++**, and **Java** programming.

source: OBTL Plan - Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Laboratory (INTHCILB)
topic: INTHCILB: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction (Laboratory)
content:
INTHCILB - **Introduction to Human Computer Interaction (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit laboratory** course (3 hrs/week) with prerequisites of **MICROB** and **MODSIMLAB**. The course introduces students to the basic concepts, theory, and methods of **Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)**. HCI is an interdisciplinary field integrating theories and methodologies from **computer science, cognitive psychology, and design**. The emphasis is on **design and evaluation** of interactive systems, with case studies used to exemplify methods. Students will gain skills for designing and evaluating interactive systems. The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) include evaluating design based on theories, defining design behavior, developing **prototype interactive interfaces**, applying concepts of modelling and task analysis, illustrating the **design cycle** using HCI guidelines, developing **adaptive systems** and **user models**, and evaluating the interactive user interface .

**The laboratory content focuses on hands-on application of HCI principles:**

* **Week 2:** **Introduction to HCI** (Evolution and brief history of HCI).
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Interactive System Design** focusing on **Usability** (Usability Engineering Life Cycle, **User-Centered Design (UCD) Methodology**) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **GUI Design & Aesthetics** (Requirements of GUI, Role of Aesthetics, Principles of Design in Visual Proportion & Rule, Psychology of Colour) .
* **Week 7:** **Prototyping** (Prototypes in HCI, **Low, Medium, and Hi Fidelity Prototypes**, and the **Wizard of Oz Technique**). Students engage in Group Activities for Prototype development .
* **Week 8:** **Model-Based Design** (Individual Models of Human Factors I, **Fitts' Law**, throughput and its measurement). .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Individual Models of Human Factors II** (Design Implications, **Speed-Accuracy Trade-off**, The **Hick-Hyman Law**), and **Guidelines in HCI** (Shneiderman's **Eight Golden Rules** of User Interface). The **Waterfall Model** is used to illustrate the design cycle .
* **Week 12:** **Guidelines in HCI** (**Norman's Seven Principles**, Norman's Model of Interaction) .
* **Week 13:** **Guidelines in HCI** (**Heuristic Evaluation**, **Nielsen's Ten Heuristics**, background of UCD framework) .
* **Week 14:** **Task Analysis** (Use of **TA Methods**, Hierarchical Task Analysis, Engineering Task Models and **CTT**) .
* **Week 15:** **The Human** (Human Processor as an information processing system, **Card, Moran, and Newell's Model (GOMS)**, Action, Perception, and Cognition) .
* **Week 16:** **Dialog Design** (**State Charts**, formal modelling of dialogs, using STN's) .
* **Week 17:** **UCSD and Advanced Technology** (Universal access, customisation, **assistive technology**, adaptable and **adaptive systems**, and **user modelling**) .

Core course materials include *Interaction Design - Beyond HCI*, *Research Methods in HCI*, and *Designing the User Interface: Strategies for Effective Human-Computer Interaction*.

source: OBTL Plan - Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Lecture (INTHCILC)
topic: INTHCILC: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction (Lecture)
content:
INTHCILC - **Introduction to Human Computer Interaction (Lecture)** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hrs/week) with prerequisites of **MICROB** and **MODSIMLEC**. This course introduces students to the basic **concepts, theory, and methods** of **Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)**. HCI is an interdisciplinary field that integrates theories and methodologies from **computer science, cognitive psychology, and design**. The course focuses on examining **design and evaluation** through case studies, aiming for students to gain principles and skills for designing and evaluating interactive systems. The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) include evaluating design based on theories, developing **prototype interactive interfaces**, applying concepts of modelling and **complex task analysis**, illustrating the **design cycle** using HCI guidelines, developing **adaptive systems** and **user models**, and evaluating interactive user interface. 

**The lecture content provides theoretical depth for HCI concepts:**

* **Week 2:** **Introduction to HCI** (Evolution and brief history of HCI) .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Interactive System Design** focusing on **Usability** (Usability Engineering Life Cycle and **User-Centered Design (UCD) Methodology**) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **GUI Design & Aesthetics** (Requirements of GUI, Role of Aesthetics, Principles of Design in Visual Proportion & Rule, Psychology of Colour) .
* **Week 7:** **Prototyping** (Prototypes in HCI, **Low, Medium, and Hi Fidelity Prototypes**, and the **Wizard of Oz Technique**) .
* **Week 8:** **Model-Based Design** (Individual Models of Human Factors I, **Fitts' Law**, throughput and its measurement) .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Individual Models of Human Factors II** (Design Implications, **Speed-Accuracy Trade-off**, The **Hick-Hyman Law**), and **Guidelines in HCI** (Shneiderman's **Eight Golden Rules** of User Interface, using the **Waterfall Model** to illustrate the design cycle) .
* **Week 12:** **Guidelines in HCI** (**Norman's Seven Principles**, Norman's Model of Interaction) .
* **Week 13:** **Guidelines in HCI** (**Heuristic Evaluation**, **Nielsen's Ten Heuristics**, background of UCD framework) .
* **Week 14:** **Task Analysis** (Use of **TA Methods**, **Hierarchical Task Analysis**, Engineering Task Models and **CTT**) .
* **Week 15:** **The Human** (Human Processor as an information processing system, **Card, Moran, and Newell's Model**, Action, Perception, and Cognition) .
* **Week 16:** **Dialog Design** (**State Charts**, formal modelling of dialogs, using STN's) .
* **Week 17:** **UCD and Advanced Technology** (Universal access, customisation, **assistive technology**, adaptable and **adaptive systems**, and **user modelling**) .

Recommended readings include influential HCI texts such as *Interaction Design - Beyond HCI*, *Research Methods in HCI*, and *Designing the User Interface: Strategies for Effective Human-Computer Interaction*.

MMDIALAB - **Multimedia (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit laboratory** course (3 hrs/week) with a prerequisite of **INTROHCI**. The course covers the **fundamentals of multimedia and intelligent systems**. Although the description mentions intelligent search, knowledge representation, and pattern recognition , the core focus, based on CILOs and weekly content, is on the **practical skills** of creating and manipulating multimedia elements. Students are trained to formulate a working definition of **interactive multimedia**, demonstrate competence in using multimedia programs, apply **animation, digitized sound, video control, and scanned images**, and use **instructional design principles** to develop conceptual maps for interactive multimedia programs .

**The laboratory content covers these topics:**

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Introduction to Multimedia** (Components, Multimedia Software Tools, and Multimedia in the Future) .
* **Weeks 4-5:** **Multimedia Tasks and Concerns** (Multimedia Production, Data Compression, Multimedia Sharing and Distribution, and Multimedia Presentation) .
* **Week 6:** **Graphics and Image Data Representation** (Graphics/Image Data Types, Popular File Formats, and demonstration of Graphics and Image Software Tools).
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Color in Image and Video** (Color Science, Color Models in Images and Video). Students perform a Group Project Simulation and Project Consultation .
* **Week 10:** **Basic of Digital Audio** (Digitization of Sound, **MIDI** (Musical Instrument Digital Interface)) .
* **Weeks 11-12:** **Multimedia Element - Sound** (Use of Sound on the Web, Basic Principles of Sound, Digital Audio Sources, Digital Audio Software, Audio File Formats for the Web, and **Editing Sounds using Audacity**) .
* **Weeks 13-14:** **Fundamental Concepts in Video** (Analog Video, Digital Video, Video Display Interfaces, 3D Video and TV, and Video Editing software) .
* **Weeks 16-17:** **Multimedia Element - Video** (Use of Video on the Web, Different Types of Video, Factors that Determine Video Quality, Video Editing Software, and the **Multimedia Project: Creating Video using a Video Editor**) .

The course explicitly uses **Audacity** for sound editing and generic **Video Editor** software for the final project. Readings include texts on **Adobe InDesign CS4, Photoshop CS4, and Illustrator CS4**, as well as *Multimedia: Making it work* and *Fundamentals of Multimedia*.

MMDIALEC - **Multimedia (Lecture)** is a **2-unit lecture** course (2 hrs/week) with a prerequisite of **INTROHCI**. The course covers fundamental issues in **intelligent systems**, intelligent search, and optimization methods, with an emphasis on **knowledge representation and reasoning**. It also includes learning **natural language understanding**, **pattern recognition**, and **knowledge-based systems**. Despite the AI/Intelligent Systems description, the core CILOs and weekly topics are focused on **multimedia production** and design principles .

Students are trained to formulate a definition of **interactive multimedia** , demonstrate the use of **animation, digitized sound, video control, and scanned images** , use basic **instructional design principles** , and create conceptual maps for interactive multimedia instructional programs. 

**The lecture content provides theoretical knowledge for multimedia production:**

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Introduction to Multimedia** (brief introduction, Components of Multimedia, Multimedia Software Tools, and Multimedia in the Future) .
* **Weeks 4-5:** **Multimedia Tasks and Concerns** (Multimedia Production process, Data Compression, Multimedia Presentation effectiveness, Multimedia Sharing and Distribution) .
* **Week 6:** **Graphics and Image Data Representation** (Graphics/Image Data Types, Popular File Formats, and demonstration of Graphics and Image Software Tools) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Color in Image and Video** (Color Science, Color Models in Images and Video) .
* **Week 10:** **Basic of Digital Audio** (Digitization of Sound, **MIDI** (Musical Instrument Digital Interface)) .
* **Weeks 11-12:** **Multimedia Element - Sound** (Use of Sound on the Web, Basic Principles of Sound, Digital Audio Sources/Software, Audio File Formats for the Web, and **Editing Sounds using Audacity**) .
* **Weeks 13-14:** **Fundamental Concepts in Video** (Analog/Digital Video, Video Display Interfaces, 3D Video and TV, and Video Editing software) .
* **Week 16:** **Multimedia Element - Video** (Use of Video on the Web, Different Types of Video, Factors that Determine Video Quality, Video Editing Software) .
* **Week 17:** **Multimedia Project** (Explanation of the multimedia project and the creation of video using a Video Editor) .

Basic Readings include texts on **Adobe InDesign CS4, Photoshop CS4, and Illustrator CS4**.

source: OBTL Plan - IPAT INTEGRATIVE PROGRAMMING AND TECHNOLOGIES (Laboratory)
content:
IPATLAB - **Integrative Programming and Technologies (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit laboratory** course (3 hrs/week) with prerequisites of **WEBDVLB2** and **INTROHCI**, and is a prerequisite for **PFORMTEC**. The course provides an overview of **integrative programming** as it relates to applications and systems. Topics include **inter-systems communication**, **data mapping and exchange**, **integrative coding**, **scripting techniques**, **software security**, and an overview of programming languages. The laboratory aims to develop the practical ability to implement, test, and debug programs using advanced programming concepts that satisfy industry requirements .

**The Course Intended Learning Outcomes (CILOs) specifically focus on hands-on skills** :

* Analyzing and using appropriate **conditional and iteration concepts** for programming tasks .
* Designing, implementing, testing, and debugging programs that use **advanced programming concepts** .
* Modifying and integrating programs that use conditional and iterative control structures and functions .
* Implementing different techniques of **structural and functional programming** .
* Preparing a framework for and developing **packages** .
* Assessing program design based on formulated industry requirements and recommending solutions .

**The weekly laboratory content is structured as follows**:

* **Week 2:** **Introduction to Integrative Programming And Technologies** (covering Programming Language, Database, and Network concepts) .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Compile vs Interpretive Language** (Describing and comparing Compile Language and Interpretive Language) .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **Application VS Scripting Language** (Describing and comparing Application Language and Scripting Language) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Integrative Coding 1** focusing on **Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)** concepts such as **Inheritance** and **Polymorphism** applied to interfaces .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Introduction To Programming** covering foundational web technologies like **HTML** and data exchange methods like **XSL, XSLT, and XPath**. This section contrasts **HTML** tags (predefined) with **XML** tags (non-predefined) used for storing and transporting data .
* **Weeks 12-13:** **Data Mapping** (Implementing XSL XSLT Data to HTML and implementing **XPATH to HTML**) .
* **Weeks 14-15:** **Scripting Technique** exploring languages and frameworks such as **PHP, JavaScript, Python, and JQuery** (covering the role, creation, and execution of scripts) .
* **Weeks 16-17:** **Integrative Coding 2** (Design Patterns, integrative coding overview, and connecting Database/Network to form a **Complete Web Application**) .

The course utilizes **PowerPoint Presentation, Module, Video Presentation, Internet Connection, and Google Classroom** for instruction and resource sharing.

source: OBTL Plan - Integrative Programming and Technologies
content:
IPATLEC - Integrative Programming and Technologies (Lecture) is a **2-unit** course with 2 hours per week. Prerequisites for this course are **WEBDVLB2** and **INTROHCI**, and it is a prerequisite for **PFORMTEC**. The course offers an overview of **integrative programming** as it relates to applications and systems. Topics covered include inter-systems communication, data mapping and exchange, integrative coding, scripting techniques, software security, and a general overview of programming languages .

The course is structured into the following major topics over 17 weeks:

* **Weeks 1-2:** Orientation and an **Introduction to Integrative Programming and Technologies**, covering the concepts of Programming Language, Database, Network, and making comparisons between **Compile vs. Interpretive Language** .
* **Weeks 3-4:** Continues the discussion on **Programming Language** focusing on Compile Language and Interpretive Language .
* **Weeks 5-6:** Focuses on the concepts of **Application vs. Scripting Language**, including describing and comparing the two .
* **Weeks 7-8:** Introduces **Integrative Coding 1**, specifically implementing advanced Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) concepts such as **Inheritance** and **Polymorphism** as applied to interfaces .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination.
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Introduction to Programming** related to the web, covering **HTML**, **XSL**, **XSLT**, and **XPath**. This includes understanding how HTML displays content and how XML is used to store and transport data, and implementing XSL/XSLT/XPath for data transformation to HTML .
* **Weeks 12-13:** Focuses on **Data Mapping** using HTML, XSL, XSLT, and XPath .
* **Weeks 14-15:** Covers **Scripting Technique** and the influence of scripting on programming, including languages such as **PHP**, **JavaScript**, **Python**, and **JQuery** .
* **Weeks 16-17:** Concludes with **Integrative Coding 2**, focusing on Design Patterns, advanced integrative coding, and implementing a **Complete Web Application** using concepts of Design Coding, Database, Network, and Web Application Connection .

By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to analyze conditional and iteration concepts, design, implement, test, and debug programs using advanced concepts, modify and integrate programs with control structures and functions, assess program designs against industry requirements, and prepare and develop a framework for creating packages. The course utilizes instructional materials like **Power Point Presentations**, **Modules/E-books**, **Video Presentations**, and tools such as **Google Classroom** and **Google Meet** for interactive discussions and online assessments.

source: OBTL Plan - Information Assurance and Security 1 (Lab)
content:
IAASLAB1 - **Information Assurance and Security 1 (Lab)** is a **1-unit** course with 3 laboratory hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is **NETWKLB**. The course serves as an introduction to the **practical aspects of IT security** for system developers, covering foundational concepts, major specialization fields, best practice, policies, procedures, ethics, and fundamental legal issues. Key topics include **risk management** and **disaster recovery** as applied to Information Assurance and Security (IAS), and addressing ethics and vulnerability issues .

This lab course trains students to describe the set of controls (technical and policy) to protect information and systems by ensuring **availability, integrity, authentication, and confidentiality**, and providing for non-repudiation. Students will also articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different security approaches .

The 18-week learning plan includes:

* **Weeks 1-2:** Introduction to **Information Security (IS)**, covering the history, characteristics, and components of an IS, balancing IS and Access, and the **Security SDLC** .
* **Weeks 3-4:** Focuses on **Threats** and **Attacks**, including Compromises to Intellectual Property, Deliberate Software Attacks, Human Error, Information Extortion, **Malicious Code, Backdoors, Password Crack, DOS/DDOS, Spam, and Man-in-the-Middle** .
* **Week 5:** Covers **Legal, Ethical, and Professional Laws** such as **Intellectual Property Law, E-Commerce Law, Data Privacy Act, and Cyber Crime Prevention Act** .
* **Week 6:** Practical application of **Risk Management**, covering Risk Identification, Assessment, and Control Strategies (Quantitative vs. Qualitative Control) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** Focuses on **Planning for Security**, including Planning and Governance, IS Policy Standards and Practices, IS Blueprint, and the **Security Education, Training, and Awareness Program** .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Security Technology**, including **Firewalls and VPNs**, **Intrusion Detection and Prevention**, and **Cryptography** (Foundations, Cipher Methods, Cryptographic Algorithm, and Tools) .
* **Weeks 12-13:** Examines **Physical Security**, covering Physical Access Controls, Fire Security and Safety, Supporting Utilities Failure, Structural Collapse, and Interception of Data (Mobile and Portable systems). 
* **Weeks 14-15:** Covers **Implementing IS**, including IS Project Management (Technical and Non-Technical), and **ISS Certification and Accreditation** .
* **Weeks 16-17:** Addresses **Security and Personnel** (Positioning, Staffing, Credentialing, Employment Practices) and **IS Maintenance** (Security Management, Maintenance Models, and **Digital Forensics**) .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination .

Learning is assessed through **Hands-on Activities, Exercises, Quizzes, Problem Sets**, and summative examinations. Recommended resources include *Principles of Information Security* by Whitman and Mattord, and certifications like **CompTia Security+, EC-Council CEH, SANS GIAC, (ISC)^2 CISSP, ISACA CISM, and Cisco CCNA Security**.

source: OBTL Plan - Information Assurance and Security 2
content:
IAASLEC2 - **Information Assurance and Security 2 (Lecture)** is a **2-unit** course with 2 hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is **IAASLEC1**. The course provides in-depth coverage of **information security models**, **software security** and systems lifecycle management, **policy development**, **personnel responsibilities**, **contingency planning**, **physical security**, **administrative controls**, and **information security assessment methods** .

This course trains students to discuss policies and practices for **systems integration and architecture** to ensure secure system operation and information assurance, perform **vulnerability analysis** of a system, and propose strategies to **counterattack threats** .

The 18-week learning plan includes the following major topics:

* **Weeks 2-3: Securing System Development Life Cycle (SDLC)**. Defines the steps and organization in the development of security systems and the role of security professionals within the organization.
* **Weeks 4-6: Network Security**. Focuses on security configuration parameters on network devices (e.g., **Firewalls, Routers, Switches, VPN concentrators**) and network security administration principles, including **Rule-based Management** (Firewall rules, VLAN Management, Port Security, 802.1x), Log Analysis, and **Network Design/Components** (Subnetting, VLAN, Remote Access, Virtualization, Layered Security).
* **Weeks 7-8: Security Implications of Integrating Systems and Data with Third Parties**. Explains policies and practices for systems integration, covering on-boarding/off-boarding, partner relationships, **Social Media networks/applications**, **Interoperability Agreements**, **Privacy Considerations**, Unauthorized Data Sharing, Data Ownership, and Data Backups.
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination.
* **Weeks 10-11: Incident Response Procedures**. Covers preparation, incident identification, escalation and notification, **Mitigation Steps**, Lessons Learned, Reporting, Recovery Procedures, **First Responder**, Incident Isolation, and Data Breach.
* **Weeks 12-13: Risk Mitigation Strategies**. Assesses counterattack strategies, including **Change Management**, **Incident Management**, User rights and Permissions, Routing Audits, enforcing Policies and Procedures, and enforcing Technology Controls.
* **Week 14: Risk Management**. Discusses **Business Continuity Concepts**, **Fault Tolerance**, and **Disaster Recovery Concepts**.
* **Weeks 15-16: Planning for Security**. Covers Planning and Governance, **IS Policy Standards and Practices**, and creating the **IS Blueprint**.
* **Week 17: Security Education Training and Awareness Program**. Proposes strategies for managing and mitigating risk, focusing on Security Policy Training, Procedures, **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)**, **Information Classification**, Data Labelling, handling and disposal, Compliance, and User habits.
* **Week 18:** Final Examination.

Recommended reading includes *Risk Management Implementation Guide* by Gerard Blokdijk, and references to industry certifications like **CompTia Security+, EC-Council CEH, SANS GIAC, and Cisco CCNA Security**.

source: OBTL Plan - Social and Professional Issues
content:
SPISSUES - **Social and Professional Issues** is a **3-unit** lecture course with 3 hours per week, intended for students with **4th year standing**. This course offers an introductory study of the diverse role computers and **information technology (IT)** play in various societies globally. It involves the analysis and discussion of the **social, political, and economic impact of computers** and IT , an examination of workplace and ethical dilemmas, and an inquiry into the **philosophical and psychological implications** of these new technologies .

The course is designed to enable students to discuss ethics and related IT concepts, define different IT users and their responsibilities, identify computer and internet crimes and their risks, discuss privacy issues, and discuss intellectual property and software development issues .

The 18-week schedule covers:

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Introduction to Ethics** and its relevance to IT, followed by **Ethics in the Business World**. Topics include the importance of good business ethics, improving corporate ethics, and creating an ethical work environment .
* **Week 4:** **Ethical Decision Making** and **Ethics in Information Technology** .
* **Weeks 5-6:** **Ethics for IT Professionals and IT Users**, defining a profession, discussing if IT workers are professionals, and covering the ethical behavior of professionals and professional **Codes of Ethics** .
* **Weeks 7-8:** Focuses on **Certification vs. Government Licensing**, IT Professional Malpractice, **IT Users and the Common Ethical Issues**, and supporting ethical practices of IT users. Professional organizations (foreign and local) are also covered .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination.
* **Weeks 10-12:** **Computer and Internet Crime**. Topics include increasing complexity/vulnerability, higher user expectations, expanding systems, new risks, reliance on commercial software with known vulnerabilities, **Types of Attacks**, Perpetrators, and methods for **Reducing Vulnerabilities** (Prevention/Detection Systems) .
* **Week 13:** **Damages of Malware**, **Combating Malware**, and **Philippine Laws on Computer/Internet Crimes**.
* **Week 14:** **Privacy**. Covers the Right of Privacy, Privacy Protection and the Law, recent history of protection (foreign and local), and **Key Privacy and Anonymity Issues** .
* **Weeks 15-16:** **Intellectual Property** issues, including Privacy Protection and the Law, and Key Privacy and Anonymity Issues .
* **Week 17:** **Software Development**, focusing on Strategies to Engineer **Quality Software** and Key Issues in Software Development .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination.

Assessment methods include Chapter tests, Quizzes, Reports, Assignments, Research Study, and a Performance Task. Required readings include *Computer Ethics* by Weckert and *Computer Ethics and Professional Responsibility* by Bynum and Rogerson.

ITTHESL2 - **Thesis 2 (Lecture)** is a **2-unit** course with 2 lecture hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is **ITTHESI1**. This course focuses on the final stages of the IT thesis, with emphasis on the outcomes of the study found in **Chapter 4 (Analysis and Presentation of Data)** and **Chapter 5 (Summary, Conclusions and Recommendations)**. The system developed as the output of the study will be checked to support the document claims during the **Final Defense** .

Students are expected to explain the theories, concepts, methodologies, and techniques used in the study, develop a logical system that solves the stated problem, and successfully defend the research paper/thesis. The goal is to complete the thesis with a well-written manuscript and a **100% functional system** .

The 18-week schedule focuses heavily on development, reporting, and defense preparation:

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Submission of Progress Report** and **Development of the system** .
* **Week 4:** **Actual Demonstration of the System** for critiquing .
* **Week 5:** **Data Gathering Process**, including identifying statistical methods and other data used in the study .
* **Week 6:** **System Development** (Hardware and/or Software) .
* **Week 7:** Submission of Progress Report .
* **Week 8:** Actual Demonstration of the System .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination (Summative Examination) .
* **Week 10:** Data Gathering Process (identifying statistical methods) .
* **Week 11:** System Development (Hardware and/or Software) focusing on demonstration for critiquing .
* **Week 12:** **Statistical Assessment of the System** and **Research presentation** .
* **Week 13:** **Tabulation and Presentation of Data** and Research presentation .
* **Week 14:** **Submission of completed documents/manuscripts (Chapter 1-5)** and Research presentation .
* **Weeks 15-16:** Final preparation, covering **Chapters 1, 2, 3, 4, 5** and **PowerPoint Presentation** (for defense) .
* **Week 17:** **System Demonstration** (Hardware and/or Software) .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination (Summative Examination) .

Teaching/Learning Activities involve group/individual reports, rubric assessment, brainstorming, problem solving, and a case study presentation (defense). The main textbook cited is *Thesis & Dissertation Writing: A Modular Approach*.

ITTHESL2 - **Thesis 2 (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit** laboratory course with 3 hours per week. The prerequisite is **ITTHESI1**. This course is focused on the practical application and validation of the IT thesis, with emphasis on the outcomes found in **Chapter 4 (Analysis and Presentation of Data)** and **Chapter 5 (Summary, Conclusions and Recommendations)**. The key objective is for the developed **system** (the output of the study) to be checked to support the document claims during the **Final Defense** .

By the end of this lab course, students are expected to explain the theories and methodologies used in the study, **develop a logical system** that solves the stated problem, and successfully defend the thesis with a well-written manuscript and a **100% functional system** .

The 18-week laboratory plan is geared towards hands-on system development, assessment, and defense preparation:

* **Weeks 2-3:** **Submission of Progress Report** and hands-on work on the **Development of the system** .
* **Week 4:** **Actual Demonstration of the System** for critiquing .
* **Week 5 & 10:** **Data Gathering Process**, including identifying **statistical methods** and other data used in the study .
* **Weeks 6 & 11:** **System Development (Hardware and/or Software)**, focusing on demonstration and critiquing of the developed system. Activities are often led by a **Gantt chart** and involve group dynamics and workshop .
* **Weeks 7 & 8:** Submission of Progress Report and Actual Demonstration/Critiquing of the system .
* **Week 9 & 18:** Midterm and Final Examinations (Summative Examination) .
* **Week 12:** **Statistical Assessment of the System** through Research presentation .
* **Week 13:** **Tabulation and Presentation of Data** through Research presentation .
* **Week 14:** **Submission of completed documents/manuscripts (Chapter 1-5)** and Research presentation .
* **Weeks 15-16:** Final preparation of the complete **Chapters 1, 2, 3, 4, 5** and **PowerPoint Presentation**, assessed via a **portfolio, project, and skills demonstration** in preparation for the case study presentation (defense) .
* **Week 17:** Final **System Demonstration (Hardware and/or Software)** .

Deliverables for almost every week are **Documentation** and a **Progress Report**. The primary textbook reference is *Thesis & Dissertation Writing: A Modular Approach*.

QUAMETLB - **Quantitative Methods (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit** lab course with 3 hours per week. The prerequisite for this course is **MMDIALEC**. This course focuses on the practical application of **quantitative data** and **quantitative analysis**. It demonstrates the processes involved in data analysis and basic **statistical analysis** .

By the end of this laboratory course, students are expected to proficiently **Understand Quantitative Analysis** and **Analyze Quantitative Data** .

The 18-week lab schedule is dedicated to hands-on application of statistical methods and data presentation:

* **Weeks 2-5:** Focuses on **Designing quantitative methods** with specific emphasis on **Survey and Experimental Designs**. Topics include defining surveys and experiments, Components of a Survey Study, the Population and Sample, Instrumentation, and developing a Method Plan. This unit also covers **Variables in Quantitative Analysis**, examining the relationships between **Independent, Dependent, Predictor, Outcome, Intervening, and Moderating Variables**. The primary output is a **Survey Instrument** .
* **Weeks 6-8:** Continues the discussion on variables, specifically **Intervening** and **Moderating Variables** .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination (Summative Examination).
* **Weeks 10-12:** **Data Analysis**. Students practice the creation of a **Data Analysis** and **Project Study** with a focus on **Steps in the Data Analysis**. This includes **Descriptive Analysis** and **Inferential Analysis**.
* **Weeks 13-14:** **Graphing Data**. Students learn to present data in graphical form, specifically **Line Graphs, Bar Graphs, Scattergrams, and Histograms**. This unit also introduces the **Stages in the Data Analysis Process**. The outputs are **Data** in **Graphical Form** and a **Project Study** .
* **Weeks 15-17:** Focuses on the stages of data analysis: **Description, Interpretation, Conclusion, and Theorization** .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination (Summative Examination) .

**Software and Tools** used for practical application include **IBM SPSS Statistics 24 for Windows and Mac, SYSTAT 13, SAS/STAT, Stata release 14**, and **MS Excel**. Recommended textbooks are *Research Methods- Structuring Inquiries and Empirical Investigation* and *Research Design- Quantitative, Qualitative, and Mixed Methods Approaches*.

source: OBTL Plan - System Administration and Maintenance (Laboratory)
content:
SYSADMLB - **System Administration and Maintenance (Laboratory)** is a **1-unit** lab course with 3 hours per week, with no prerequisites. This course provides a practical understanding of the deployment and maintenance of modern computer systems, with a particular emphasis on **user accounts administration**. The lab includes hands-on basic administrative tasks associated with **Network Operating Systems (NOS)** such as **Windows and Linux**. Students will cover the installation and configuration of mainstream operating systems, important **network services**, **disaster recovery** procedures, and techniques for ensuring system **security** .

Students are trained to proficiently **learn and apply basic concepts and methodologies of System Administration and Security** by **building a miniature corporate network from the ground up**. They will install backend servers, validate network functionality from a user's perspective, and implement security measures with subsequent risk assessment .

**Key hands-on lab topics include:**

* **Weeks 2:** **Networking Overview** (Protocol Standard, OS Model, **TCP/IP**, Windows/Linux Network, Switching/Routing Basics) .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Server Administration** (Server/Client Installation, Boot Process, Startup Services, **Managing Accounts**, File System, Disk Quota Management, Job Scheduling, Process Controlling, Online Server update/upgrade) .
* **Weeks 5-6 (Part 1):** **Network Configuration** (IPv4/IPv6 Addressing, Network Interface Configuration, Network Troubleshooting Commands, **Linux and Windows Firewall Configurations**) .
* **Weeks 6 (Part 2):** **Static and DHCP** (Principles, Configuration, Options, Scope, Reservations, Relaying, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Name Server and Configuration** (**DNS Principles** and operations, Basic Name Server and Client Configuration, Caching Only, Primary and Slave Name Servers, DNS Zone Transfers, Dynamic Update, Delegation, Server Security, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Web and Proxy Server Configuration** (**HTTP Server**, **Virtual Hosting**, HTTP Caching, **Proxy Caching Server Configuration**, Proxy ACL, Proxy-Authentication Mechanism, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Weeks 12-13:** **FTP, File and Print Server** (Introduction to **Samba**, Samba Configuration/SWAT, NFS/NFS Client Configuration, **CUPS Configuration**, FTP Principles/Server, Printer Configuration/Setup/Local/AppSocket/Samba Printer, Printing a Test Page, Modifying Existing Printers) .
* **Week 14:** **Mail Server** (**SMTP, POP, IMAP Principles**, SMTP Relaying, Mail Domain Administration, Mail Server Configuration, **SPAM Control and Filtering**, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Week 15:** **Remote Administration and Management** (**Router Configuration**, Web admin/User Admin, **Team Viewer**, **Telnet**, **SSH**) .
