* **Week 16:** **Configuration and Maintenance** (System Configuration Policy, Controlling Causes/Symptoms, **Change Management**, Policy Configuration/Ethical usage, Clock Synchronizations, Human-Computer Job Scheduling, Prevention Host Maintenance) .
* **Week 17:** **Security and Implementation** (System Design and Normalization, The **Recovery Plan**, **Data Integrity and Protections**, Authentication Methods, Analyzing Network Security, **Role based Security**, **IPSec**, **IP filtering**, **Firewalls**, **Intrusion Detection and Forensic**) .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination .

Required reading includes materials on **Windows Server 2008** and **Group Policy**.

source: OBTL Plan - System Administration and Maintenance (Lecture)
content:
SYSADMLC - **System Administration and Maintenance (Lecture)** is a **2-unit** lecture course with 2 hours per week, with no prerequisites. This course provides a theoretical understanding of the deployment and maintenance of modern computer systems, with particular emphasis on **user accounts administration**. The course includes an overview of the concepts and basic administrative tasks associated with **Network Operating Systems (NOS)** such as **Windows and Linux**. Topics cover the installation and configuration principles of mainstream operating systems, important **network services**, **disaster recovery** procedures, and techniques for ensuring system **security** .

Students are expected to **learn and apply basic concepts and methodologies of System Administration and Security** by conceptualizing the components of a miniature corporate network. This includes understanding the installation of backend servers, validating network functionality from a user's perspective, and applying security measures with a focus on risk assessment .

**Key lecture topics include:**

* **Week 2:** **Networking Overview** (History, Protocol Standard, **OS Model, TCP/IP**, Windows/Linux Network, **Switching and Routing Basics**) .
* **Weeks 3-4:** **Server Administrations** (Server/Client Installation planning, Boot Process and Startup Services, **Managing Accounts**, File System, Disk Quota Management, Job Scheduling, Process Controlling, Online Server upgrade/update process) .
* **Weeks 5-6 (Part 1):** **Network Configuration** (**IPv4/IPv6 Addressing**, Network Interface Configuration, Diagnosing Network, **Linux and Windows Firewall Configurations**, Network Troubleshooting Commands) .
* **Week 6 (Part 2):** **Static and DHCP** (Principles, Configuration, Static Versus DHCP, DHCP Server Configuration, Options, Scope, Reservations, Relaying, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Weeks 7-8:** **Name Server and Configuration** (**DNS Principles** and operations, Basic Name Server and Client Configuration, Caching Only, Primary and Slave Name Server, DNS Zone Transfers, Dynamic Update, Delegation, Server Security, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination .
* **Weeks 10-11:** **Web and Proxy Server Configuration** (**HTTP Server**, **Virtual Hosting**, HTTP Caching, **Proxy Caching Server Configuration**, Proxy ACL, Proxy-Authentication Mechanism, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Weeks 12-13:** **FTP, File and Print Server** (Introduction to **Samba**, Configuration/SWAT, NFS/NFS Client Configuration, **CUPS Configuration**, FTP Principles/Server, Printer Configuration/Setup/Samba Printer, and Modifying Existing Printers) .
* **Week 14:** **Mail Server** (**SMTP, POP, IMAP Principles**, SMTP Relaying, Mail Domain Administration, Mail Server Configuration, **SPAM Control and Filtering**, and Troubleshooting) .
* **Week 15:** **Remote Administration and Management** (**Router Configuration**, Web admin/User Admin, **Team Viewer, Telnet, SSH**) .
* **Week 16:** **Configuration and Maintenance** (System Configuration Policy, Controlling Causes/Symptoms, **Change Management**, Policy Configuration/Ethical usage, Clock Synchronizations, Human-Computer Job Scheduling, Prevention Host Maintenance) .
* **Week 17:** **Security and Implementation** (System Design/Normalization, The **Recovery Plan**, **Data Integrity and Protections**, Authentication Methods, Analyzing Network Security, **Role based Security**, **IPSec, IP filtering, Firewalls, Intrusion Detection and Forensic**) .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination .

Required readings reference materials on **Windows Server 2008** and **Group Policy**.

ITINTERN - **Practicum/Internship** is a **1-unit** laboratory course with 3 hours per week, which requires a **4th Year Standing** prerequisite. This course is designed to **expose students to practical work** expected of an Information Technology graduate , such as a computer programmer, software engineer, systems/applications software developer, data analyst, quality assurance specialist, or software support specialist. The total work requirement is **450 hours of on-the-job training (OJT)**, plus **36 hours for briefing and orientation**. The training is to be conducted in different Industrial and Commercial IT companies .

Students are expected to: **integrate and apply theory** from their IT courses in a work environment; **use common techniques and skills** of the IT field; **observe and take part in the management of technology changes**; **understand the industry environment** of the organization; **demonstrate community involvement** ; and **perform various tasks** to the supervisor's satisfaction .

**The 18-week schedule focuses on OJT preparation, deployment, and documentation:**

* **Week 1:** **Course Orientation** and review of school/college goals .
* **Weeks 2-3:** **Preparation of the Internship Program** including: Orientation of practicum works; presentation of listings of industrial companies ; writing and submission of an **Application Letter** and **Curriculum Vitae**; submission of the application letter to chosen industries; and preparation of the **Memorandum of Agreement** (MOA) (which must be notarized).
* **Weeks 4-8:** **Actual On-the-Job Training**. Deployment of students to OJT partners ; submission of a **weekly reflective narrative report** ; and consultation/visitation by the instructor. Outputs include the **Daily Time Record** and the **Narrative Report/Journal** .
* **Week 9:** Midterm Examination (Summative Examination).
* **Weeks 10-17:** **Actual On-the-Job Training (Continued)**. Continued deployment and submission of weekly reflective narrative reports , alongside consultation/visitation by the internship coordinator .
* **Week 18:** Final Examination (Summative Examination) .

The primary learning material is the **Computing Programs Internship Guidebook**.
